content: tt ii pp slip_stitch ++ tt rr ii cc kk slip_stitch inserting into the back bump of the foundation row is an aesthetic choice i find it looks neater but you re welcome to insert your hook the normal way instead you may find the gauge of the fpdc/bpdc to be tighter than that of the hhdc section you can either loosen your gauge to accommodate this and/or block your work at the end to make it more uniform i like to place my new chains into the former chains rather than the chain space to keep a cleaner edge that also removes larger holes along the sides i used a smaller hook to reduce the gaps in the stitches when wet but you can experiment with a smaller or larger hook to get the density you prefer i like to use colour changing yarn for the hhdc section and solid yarn for the fpdc/bpdc the hhdc is physically flat so the colour changing yarn brings some depth to it while the texture of the fpdc/bpdc is already interesting to look at so a solid yarn is perfect i played around with different colour combinations see page 5 herringbone half_double_crochet step-by-step guide with photos 1 yarn over 2 insert hook into stitch 3 pull up a loop 3 loops on the hook 4 slip new loop through middle loop 2 loops on the hook 5 yarn over 6 pull through both loops 3 pp hh oo tt oo gg uu ii dd ee locating the back bump rotate foundation chain 90 degrees towards you back bump are here cchhaaiinnss bbaacckk bbuummppss 11 11 22 22 1st chain in your chain 2 space fpdc/bpdc pattern will become intuitive as the name suggests you ll find the white section great for scrubbing and the gray for buffing 4 tt hh aa nn kk yy oo uu thank you for purchasing my pattern this design was so much fun to create and i hope you get a lot of use out of your own scrub + buff cloth 5
